evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary pushback control lapse: active tug instructor failed to stop at TRP. NEC: The required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with; Pushback movement continued beyond TRP until blast-fence contact

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary coordination failure: challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew. NEC: Crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent; No timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary environmental/marking deficiency at TRP. NEC: TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate; The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary mechanical or control-system failure. NEC: A tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affected stopping; Corroboration exists via tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary coordination failure occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as documented in the preliminary historical timeline, indicating the issue was present and observable in this specific context.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The coordination failure is resistant to defeaters as it is supported by multiple cues and the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, making alternative explanations less plausible given the documented crew assumptions and communication gaps.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure aligns with key features of communication breakdowns, including divergent assumptions among ground crew about stop-state or intent and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

slot_statements.availability: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t0_prelim phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The root cause analysis resists defeaters by confirming that the active tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP was the direct cause of the pushback movement continuing beyond the TRP, with no alternative explanations or mitigating factors identified.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The incident fits key features of procedural deviation where the NEC condition of reaching but not complying with the TRP stop/release point is met, as pushback continued beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact.

node.statement: The primary coordination failure occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as documented in the preliminary historical timeline, indicating the issue was present and observable in this specific context.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are the relevant stop-state indicator for coordination.
The continuation beyond TRP with engine idle implies a failure in crew coordination and communication.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was clearly communicated and understood by all crew before exceedance, or if mechanical failure evidence emerged.
If the pushback procedural deviation (R1) evidence was stronger or more directly linked to the event.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the aircraft passing the TRP and continuing beyond it, indicating a coordination failure consistent with R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN in the specific context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew communication details and lack of explicit challenge or alert timing evidence

node.statement: The failure aligns with key features of communication breakdowns, including divergent assumptions among ground crew about stop-state or intent and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

assumptions: The absence of explicit mention of challenge or stop warnings implies they did not occur effectively
The continued movement beyond TRP despite cues indicates failure in communication and coordination
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely challenge or shared understanding of stop-state among crew
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 shows divergent assumptions and lack of effective challenge or stop warnings among ground crew, supporting the communication breakdown claim; H4 shows the consequence of this failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity remains about exact communication content and timing of challenge attempts

node.statement: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t0_prelim phase.

assumptions: The instructor recognized the TRP and was expected to stop but failed to do so.
No mechanical or communication failures caused the pushback to continue beyond the TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or poorly marked to the instructor, or if mechanical faults caused unintended movement, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H3 shows the instructor actively controlling pushback and attentive, while H4 confirms the aircraft passed the TRP and collided with the blast fence, supporting the claim of a procedural lapse (R1) rather than environmental or marking deficiency (R3).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on TRP visibility or marking adequacy; possible ambiguity if environment contributed.

node.statement: The incident fits key features of procedural deviation where the NEC condition of reaching but not complying with the TRP stop/release point is met, as pushback continued beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact.

assumptions: The tug instructor was in control and responsible for stopping at the TRP
No mechanical faults were reported or observed that would explain pushback beyond TRP
defeaters: If evidence showed a verified braking or control fault causing uncontrolled pushback beyond TRP
If evidence indicated the TRP was not reached or recognized by the tug instructor

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly states the nosewheel reached the TRP but pushback continued beyond it until blast-fence contact, supporting the procedural deviation claim (R1) over mechanical failure (R4).

node.statement: The coordination failure is resistant to defeaters as it is supported by multiple cues and the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, making alternative explanations less plausible given the documented crew assumptions and communication gaps.

assumptions: No mechanical fault evidence exists beyond what is provided.
Crew communication and actions as described are complete and accurate.
defeaters: If fault codes, tests, or repeat malfunctions indicated mechanical control failure, this would favor R4 and challenge the coordination failure resistance claim.
If evidence showed effective challenge or stop warnings were given and ignored, undermining the claim of lack of effective challenge.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 documents crew roles, actions, and the failure to stop at the TRP despite cues, supporting coordination failure (R2) and lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, making mechanical failure (R4) less plausible.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical faults or hardware failure is presented; ambiguity remains if mechanical issues contributed.

slot_statements.availability: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently observable and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident dated 12-25, with corroboration from tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures confirming its presence.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is resistant to defeaters, supported by multiple independent tests, diagnostics, and repeat failure occurrences in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 case.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions affecting stopping performance, as evidenced by the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 preliminary historical data.

slot_statements.availability: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim timeframe.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: No credible evidence or alternative explanations effectively refute the conclusion that the TRP marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim data.

node.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently observable and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident dated 12-25, with corroboration from tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures confirming its presence.

defeaters: Presence of fault codes, diagnostic test results, or repeatable mechanical/control failures documented in the incident
Direct evidence of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affecting stopping

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and collided with the blast barrier without documented mechanical or control-system failure; no corroboration via tests or diagnostics is present, favoring environment/marking deficiency over mechanical failure.
